The program includes a system for personnel to communicate with management on matters relating to occupational safety and health, including provisions designed to encourage employees to inform management of hazards at the worksite without fear of reprisal.
The safety communications system, one of the elements of the IIPP, is readily available and understandable to all affected employees. 
The safety communication system includes:
 	Meetings 
 	Training programs 
 	Postings 
 	Written communications 
 	A system for anonymous notification by employees about hazards 
 	Labor/management safety and health committees 
 	Tail gate or tool box meetings
In addition to the above, during Construction the IIPP requires that Manager's conduct toolbox or tailgate safety meetings with their crews at least every ten working days to empha safety. Managers also hold periodic meetings to discuss safety problems and accidents that have occurred.
The completed IIPP is filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices

Pre-Startup Review
Pre-startup safety reviews are required on all new or modified equipment/systems. This involves process safety information, process hazard analysis, training, safety procedures, operating procedures, and verification that construction and equipment are in accord with the design specifications.

See the Prevention Program Element 7 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

Compliance Audits
To insure that all the other 12 areas of PSM program are followed, the company requires compliance audits.  At a minimum, these must be completed every three years. Resubmission of the RMP shall be done according to requirements.

See the Prevention Program Element 8 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

Incident Investigation
An incident investigation shall be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of ammonia. The purpose is to gain information that could prevent further accidents and to identify weaknesses in the emergency response plan that need to be addressed. Investigations are initiated promptly using a trained team. The findings and recommendations will be studied and appropriate corrective action taken.

See the Prevention Program Element 9 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

Employee Participation
The Employee Participation Program is an asset to both employees at the site and to the community as a whole.  As a general rule, employees who are fully involved have a greater sense of responsibility; they are more likely to catch the problems that can cause acc

idents. Employee awareness is for employees, not directly involved with the process, this includes knowing the hazards, the safety rules, warning signs, and evacuation procedures. All employees have access to the PSM Program. Involved employees participate directly in every phase of the PSM program, including conducting the PHA, developing or reviewing operating procedures, reviewing incident investigations, and conducting mechanical integrity and compliance audits.

Community involvement is through coordination and cooperation with the local Fire department and CUPA.

See the Prevention Program Element 10 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

Hot Work and Safe Work Practices
This permit process is to protect against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (welding and cutting outside the designated areas).  Hot work permits must be obtained before any work is done outside the shop area. Maintenance reviews and issues the permits to insure all fire prevention and protection rules are met. Permits indicate the appropriate dates and the work to be done. The permits are kept on file until workers have completed the hot work operation and the fire watch is completed.

See the Prevention Program Element 11 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

Contractors and Contractor Qualifications
This site follows strict guidelines for qualifying contractors who directly influence the safety of the process or the system. The contractor qualification procedure ensures that contractors and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with the ammonia process, that contractors understand their responsibility and train their people, and that a contractor's safety record is considered in reviewing the bids.

California Dairies, Inc. revised this document in May of 2011 from a program level 2 to program level 3.

California Dairies, Inc. (California Dairies) in Los Banos, California, prepared a Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management Program (RMP/PSM) in general accordance with state and federal regulations. The state risk management regulations, also referred to as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program, are codified in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Section 2735.1, et. Seq. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also regulates facilities with certain toxic and flammable substances. The regulations are codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. Finally, both the Occupational Safety and Health Association (OSHA) and the California Occupational Safety and Health Association (CalOSHA) regulate facilities with certain acutely hazardous materials under the PSM regulations, as defined in CCR Title 8, Section 5189 and CFR Title 29, Part 1910, Section 119, respectively.

SCOPE
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 

Note: This summary includes additional information not included in the RMP Submit to assist California Dairies Inc. management, process operators, technicians, contractors plus all involved and affected employees towards safe operation. In addition some of the detail provided within this summary was excluded from the submitted RMP as current public access to this detail could expose the facility and personnel to terrorist or criminal activity.

These processes do not meet the requirements of Program 1. They are subject to OSHA's PSM standard.  Therefore, this RMP is written to meet the EPA Program 3 level of compliance. To reduce confusion and to keep procedures and programs consistent all processes have been identified as Program Level 3 and developed as such.

This program was created 9/1/10 through

7/23/2011 to meet the required initial State and Federal submittal. 

The following areas are addressed in this summary:

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
2.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3.	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including
   administrative controls and mitigation measures 
4.	The accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps
5.	The five-year accident history
6.	The emergency response program
7.	Planned changes to improve safety


A-1	 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

California Dairies Inc. is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. California Dairies Inc. has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.

State regulations require reporting when there is an accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  California Dairies Inc. interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedures that may prevent future incidents.

Any release of more than 25 ppm may result

in immediately shutting down the ammonia systems depending on the location of the release. The Plant Manager and Maintenance are to be called if not on site for support.  Releases less than 25 PPM shall result in immediately calling the Plant Manager and Maintenance, if not on site, for instructions.

The facility utilizes inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment on an ongoing basis and prior to changes. These procedures identify potential sources of release, administrative and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel, registered engineers, refrigeration experts, and certified refrigeration contractors as required review the equipment and administrative procedures and engineering controls.

There are additional full time Managers and operational employees at this facility in addition to Maintenance that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia systems on a regular basis. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release immediately.  An example would be excessive rust on piping or tanks. This team activity is the core of California Dairies Inc.'s prevention program.  


A-2	STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The California Dairies Inc. facility provides production, product cooling, and short-term storage of Dairy Products. Stationary systems (engine rooms) are operated year round 24/7.
The facility is located in an industrial area of Merced County on a contiguous property. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the two Refrigeration Systems. The total ammonia inventory in Process 1 at 11,000 lbs. exceeds the Federal and State thresholds. Processes 1 and 2 exceed the state threshold of 500 lbs.

The refrigeration systems are direct, mechanical closed loop refrigeration systems. The facility was built prior to 1981 and modified since then.

The ammonia equipment is located in a machinery room, outside and in the refrigerated r

ooms.

A-3 	HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), include administrative controls and mitigation measures. The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. 

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely unlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition Process 1 & 2 components are separated by walls and distance. Furthermore as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

A-4	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
California Dairies Inc.'s Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by California Dairies Inc. is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of California Dairies Inc.'s Prevention Program are briefly described below:

1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by California Dairies Inc..  (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Mechanical Integrity Elements).

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (

Addressed under Operating Procedures, Mechanical Integrity, and Incident Investigation Elements.) 

4) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system.  California Dairies Inc. certifies operators following completion of operator training and California Dairies Inc.'s confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all California Dairies Inc. employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Employee Participation Element)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by California Dairies Inc.'s (Management of Change Procedure) 
 
If a mechanical change is required and for maintenance contracts, California Dairies Inc. has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other Hot Work occurs close to the refrigeration system, a California Dairies Inc. Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 

Following completion of a

mechanical change, a pre-startup safety review is required before the system can be charged or started. (These areas are addressed under Management of Change, Contractor Qualifications, Hot Work Permit, and Pre-Start-up Safety Review Elements.)

7) Verification of California Dairies Inc.'s compliance with the RMP/PSM program.  This self-audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program (and the Risk Management Program) has been implemented and properly documented by California Dairies Inc. personnel.  California Dairies Inc. has established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit chapter.)   

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under California Dairies Inc.'s Injury and Illness Prevention Program)

INJURY AND ILLINESS/ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
This facility follows the EPA's 40CFR68 Risk Management Plan and OSHA's 29CFR1910.119 Process Safety Management Program.  In addition the plan satisfies the State of California's Injury and Illness Prevention Program requirements CCR Title 8 3203.
In California, every employer is required by law to provide a safe and healthful workplace to his/her employees. In accordance with the California Code of Regulations, California Dairies Inc. has an effective written Injury and Illness Prevention Program (IIPP). 
The IIPP is a written plan that covers the following elements:
 	Management commitment/assignment of responsibilities 
 	Safety communications system with employees 
 	System for assuring employee compliance with safe work practices 
 	Scheduled inspections/evaluation system 
 	Accident investigation 
 	Procedures for correcting unsafe/unhealthy conditions 
 	Safety and health training and instruction 
 	Recordkeeping and documentation 
The IIPP includes procedures that California Dairies Inc. personnel must put into practice. It is both the employer's and employee's responsibi

erate, maintain, or repair the process equipment or piping. There are three major categories of information: ammonia data such as MSDS, safety information, first aid, chemical properties, IIAR safety bulletins, etc.; process information such as piping & instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), block flow diagram, design codes and standards, pressure safety relief settings, safety system/devices, ventilation system design, operating procedures, safe operating limits, and ramification of process deviation; and process equipment information such as equipment specifications, electrical classifications, materials of construction, installation manuals, operating and maintenance manuals, and manufacturer's manuals.

Process Hazard Analysis
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was completed using the What-if checklist.  This addressed hazards, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, external events and a qualitative evaluation of the possible safety and health impact. The results of the PHA were prioritized and incorporated into a PHA Findings Report for follow-up as a corrective action log.

See Element 2 of the Prevention Program for the complete guidelines
The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices

See the Prevention Program Element 3 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

Training
All employees who are involved with anhydrous ammonia have been properly trained, at a minimum, in understanding the MSDS, routine refrigeration system operation, emergency refrigeration system operation, emergency and normal refrigeration safety practices, and the individual's role in the emergency response plan or action plan.

See the Prevention Program Element 4 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Human Resources Office.

Mechanical Integrity
The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity Audit program is to ensure that the equipment is maintained in good working condition.   Inspections, and ongoing maintenance based on industry standards are performed on all compressors, condensers, evaporators, pressure vessels, piping systems, relief/vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps etc.

See the Prevention Program Element 5 for the complete guidelines. The supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.
 
Management of Change
The Management of Change (MOC) procedure requires that all changes (even replacement in kind) be reviewed to see if there is a possible negative effect. The MOC review addresses the technical basis for the change, the impact on safety and health, modifications to operating procedures, and authorization requirements for the proposed change.  Employees affected by the change are informed of the change before startup and trained in the proper procedures.

supporting and completed documents are filed and maintained in the Administrative Offices.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE/ACTION PROGRAM
This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response/Action Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as Los Banos Fire and the Merced County Environmental Health Department, Division of Environmental Health. The facilities emergency response plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 

The facility has coordinated with outside parties through drills and attendance at Ammonia Safety Days. Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. In addition Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities capabilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release.

Detailed plans (emergency action plans) have been developed to assist responders and company personnel.  All areas (zones) can be brought under control within 20 minutes of any ammonia emergency or breakdown if personnel/contractors are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immediately.  

The emergency release response plan for all releases is to gain access to the shut down valves and controls for the system with the release.  If the system shut down areas are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate.  The appropriate shut down switches and controls are identified at the facility.  

The facility will assist outside agencies during large releases of hazardous chemicals. All personnel will evacuate to the meeting areas
